paper_metadata.title: Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP) program impacts on labor transitions in Ghana

program_information.target_population: Poor and vulnerable households with orphans/vulnerable children, elderly persons with limited work capacity, or persons with disabilities

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: The Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP) program is Ghana's first social protection program to provide cash and health insurance to the poor and vulnerable | A pilot of the cash transfer program was initiated in 2008 and expanded through 2012, and provided financial assistance in the form of cash and health insurance to indigent households

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: we considered three main labor shifts. The first shift was from being unemployed to being employed. This transition was considered as the main labor shift. Further, the analysis examined the specific employment type: wage employment or selfemployment

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: The Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP) program is Ghana's first social protection program to provide cash and health insurance to the poor and vulnerable
evidence_citations.country_citation: In Ghana, the Livelihood Empowerment Against Poverty (LEAP) program is implemented as a social cash transfer mechanism under the National Social Protection Strategy
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: the eligibility for participation was based on poverty and the presence of an orphan or vulnerable child, an elderly person with limited capacity to work, or a person with a disability within a household
